I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The United Nations (UN) System of National Accounts (SNA) constitutes the most widely 
used framework for the comprehensive presentation of macroeconomic statistical data. It was 
designed for economic analysis, policymaking, decision making, and evaluating countries’ level 
of  development.  The  SNA  adopts  internationally  accepted  concepts,  definitions,  and 
classifications,  and  it  allows  for  cross-country  comparisons.  In  February  1993,  the  United 
Nations Statistical Commission (UNSC) adopted the 1993 SNA, the third version of the SNA, 
following the second in 1968. The 1993 SNA accommodates the evolution of economies since 
the 1968 SNA and takes into account advances in methodological research and the expanded 
needs of users.  
 
2.  Fifteen years since the introduction of the 1993 SNA, developing member countries 
(DMCs) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) are still a long way from implementing it. 
Available  statistics  indicate  the  DMCs  lag  behind  not  only  developed  countries  but  also 
countries in transition. This technical assistance is part of a continuous effort on the part of ADB 
to further facilitate the implementation of the 1993 SNA. This is imperative if DMCs are to catch 
up and position themselves to deal with the additional issues arising from the ongoing revision 
of the 1993 SNA (1993 SNA revision 1), which is expected to be implemented in 2009. While 
past technical assistance on national accounts has largely been for individual countries, the 
proposed technical assistance is regional. The recently concluded regional technical assistance 
(RETA) 6088, Strengthening and Collection of Purchasing Power Parity (PPP) Data in Selected 
Developing Member Countries, included 21 developing member economies and showcased the 
success that projects implemented as regional initiatives can enjoy. The proposed RETA is 
recommended to be implemented along similar lines, to bring together participating countries 
into satisfactory conceptual compliance and expand the scope of implementation of the 1993 
SNA. Data inadequacy is reportedly the main impediment to implementing the 1993 SNA. 
Supply and use tables (SUTs) provide the most appropriate and comprehensive way to identify 
data gaps, assess data quality, and in the process assist in strengthening the data systems of 
DMCs. While the regular conduct of statistical activities such as establishment surveys is still 
the best way to meet the data needs for national account compilation, these activities require 
extensive resources. They are often low priorities for governments of DMCs, whose primary 
concerns  are  understandably  the  provision  of  basic  social  services  such  as  health  and 
education. Hence, alternative data sources will be investigated and explored such as, but not 
limited to, administrative data. The RETA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The  UNSC  monitors  1993  SNA  implementation  in  accordance  with  an  assessment 
framework using compliance with 1993 SNA concepts and scope of accounts. Conceptual 
compliance covers the inclusion of items affecting levels of gross domestic product (GDP) and 
gross national income. Recent information from the UNSC on these indicators is summarized in 
the following tables. Table 1 shows the conceptual implementation of the 1993 SNA. Out of 38 
countries  in  Asia,  only  17,  or  45%,  have  achieved  conceptual  compliance.  The  recent 
experience of ADB in the 2005 International Comparison Program for Asia and the Pacific (ICP 
Asia  Pacific)  further  highlighted  the  need  to  assist  countries  in  their  efforts  to  meet  the 
requirements of the 1993 SNA. Of the 21 participating DMCs in ICP Asia Pacific, only four, or 
19%, reported full 1993 SNA implementation, while the others were at various stages and/or 
levels of adoption.

4.  The scope of implementation is measured by what is termed the "minimum requirement 
dataset," which comprises seven tables recommended by the UN Statistical Division (UNSD) 
and indicates progress toward adopting the 1993 SNA. It is a prerequisite that countries compile 
the minimum set of tables before the 1993 SNA is considered to have been implemented. 
Based on this criterion, only 50% of countries in Asia have compiled six or more tables, and 
18%  more  than  seven  tables.  These  compliance  rates  are  substantially  lower  than  in  the 
developed and transition economies, which stand at 73% for six or more tables and 57% for 
seven or more tables.

5.  A UNSD survey of 1993 SNA non-implementers showed that data inadequacy is the 
main impediment to compiling national accounts, followed by, in order of importance, the lack of 
knowledge,  inadequate  number,  and  turnover,  of  staff.  While  numerous  initiatives  by 
international agencies have aimed to remedy these shortcomings, they have been undertaken 
mainly by area of expertise or mandate, such as agriculture, industry, services, prices, labor, 
household income and expenditure statistics, and international trade. These initiatives have had 
the desired outcome because they have been partial responses encompassing only a subset of 
basic economic statistics.

3 
   
6.   UNSC has seen it necessary to update the 1993 SNA to maintain the relevance of the 
system in a rapidly changing world. Globalization, developments and innovations in financial 
markets,  and  the  growing  importance  of  non-financial  assets  (such  as  research  and 
development and databases) were among the motivations for the update. UNSC commissioned 
the project to update the 1993 SNA in March 2003 and, in February 2008, formally adopted the 
1993 SNA revision 1 as the new international standard for compiling national accounts and as 
the unifying framework for the integration of economic and related statistics. While the update 
does not recommend fundamental changes to the 1993 SNA, a list of 44 issues has been 
recommended for inclusion. It is expected that the 1993 SNA revision 1 will be finalized in 2009. 
Lest  DMCs  become  laggards  a  second  time  around,  assisting  them  to  enhance  their 
implementation of the 1993 SNA warrants consideration. 
  
7.  ADB is actively involved in monitoring poverty incidence and severity in the region and 
accessing  performance  against  the  first  Millennium  Development  Goal  (MDG)  of  halving 
absolute poverty by 2015. The last 2 decades have seen measures of poverty that use $1 per 
day or $2 per day as a guiding principle increasingly adopted by international organizations and 
policymakers. The use of $1 per day and $2 per day international poverty lines was initiated by 
the World Bank for compiling national, regional and global poverty estimates. The current 
practice is to convert the international poverty line into local currency using purchasing power 
parity  (PPP)  for  the  consumption  aggregate  of  the  national  accounts.  If  the  consumption 
aggregate is flawed, this carries into PPP computation, causing under- or overestimation of PPP 
and levels of poverty. It is extremely desirable that national account estimates be sufficiently 
reliable to assist in sound decision making.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.   Impact and Outcome 
8.  At the onset, the RETA is expected to increase the implementation of international 
standards in macroeconomic statistics, with particular focus on national accounts, by improving 
compliance with the 1993 SNA. This will allow more reliable GDP estimates for informed policy 
and decision making. The RETA seeks to help participating DMCs adopt the SUT framework 
toward implementing the 1993 SNA, with particular focus on achieving minimum compliance 
and scope requirements. Specifically, the RETA is intended to (i) establish the supply and use 
framework for data gap assessment and GDP estimation based on the 1993 SNA, (ii) identify 
appropriate administrative data sources in addition to survey data for the construction of a SUT, 
(iii) develop a framework to derive sufficiently detailed expenditure weights such as those 
required for PPP compilation, (iv) increase the compliance of participating DMCs with 1993 SNA 
recommendations, and (v) improve technical expertise and expose national accountants in the 
DMCs to alternative approaches for compiling consistent GDP aggregates based on the 1993 
SNA. The delivery of these outputs will ensure that participating DMCs acquire more reliable 
and  accurate  data  for  both  monitoring  the  achievement  of  MDGs  related  to  poverty  and 
measuring economic output. Upon the successful completion of the RETA, selected DMCs will 
be in a better position to take on the additional challenges of the 1993 SNA revision 1.  
 
B.   Methodology and Key Activities

10.  The identification of DMCs to participate in the RETA will be based on the reports of 
countries that participated in the 2005 ICP Asia Pacific2. Bearing in mind the detailed data 
requirements  for  implementing  the  RETA,  it  is  recommended  that  participating  DMCs  be 
grouped  by  level  of  compliance  and  scope  of  implementation  of  the  1993  SNA,  which  is 
basically measured in terms of satisfying the minimum requirement datasets. Assessment of 
countries based on these two criteria will help determine data availability and the level of 
statistical capacity. Initial institutional capacity assessment is proposed, to be conducted by the 
ADB Economics and Research Department’s Development Indicators and Policy Research 
Division,  in  consultation  with  the  countries.  An  invitation  letter  to  determine  interest  in 
participating in the RETA will be sent to DMCs.  
 
11.  The construction of the supply and use framework will involve the review of concepts 
and methodologies related to the 1993 SNA compilation, as well as industrial, establishment, 
and household expenditure surveys; investment surveys; and foreign trade statistics, among 
other things. Economies’ sources of products (domestic production plus imports) will then be 
identified and classified in the supply table. Likewise, the uses of the products (intermediate 
consumption, final consumption, and export) and other primary factors, as well as the derivation 
of  gross  value  added  (the  difference  between  gross  output  and  intermediate 
consumption/intermediate inputs of goods and services in production) will then be developed to 
make up the use tables. The two tables will then be linked to form a matrix table such that the 
total supply of a product will always be equal to the total use of that product. 
 
12.  Data availability is significant for 1993 SNA implementation. As mentioned above, the 
UNSD survey to investigate underlying factors that impede the implementation of 1993 SNA 
shows that data availability, both in scope and frequency, is the main obstacle. The survey 
indicated that most developing countries currently adopt a recommended data collection cycle 
of economic censuses as benchmarks, followed by annual and more frequent surveys. In 
contrast,  most  developed  countries  (75%)  and  transition  economies  (93%)  have  adopted 
alternative approaches that rely on annual and more frequent surveys in combination with 
administrative data. This latter approach will be recommended to participating DMCs, as it 
maximizes the use of administrative sources, minimizes the response burden, and cuts costs, 
while providing information of near-census quality.  
 
13.  Training course(s) and/or workshops for national statistical offices (NSOs) and relevant 
agencies will be conducted on the compilation of national accounts, with particular focus on the 
minimum requirement datasets. These will include assessing the reasons for low compliance, 
identifying  data  gaps  and  possible  solutions  to  address  data  gap  issues  and  improve 
compliance. A model similar to the 2005 ICP experience will be used to ensure output delivery: 
an initial workshop to identify data gaps and possible data sources, with follow-up workshops 
where problems and solutions are discussed. The DMCs will then adopt the proposed solutions 
and report at a final workshop. Technical assistance shall be provided as needed, depending on 
individual country requirements. 
 
14.  At the Development Indicators and Policy Research Division, staff will have acquired 
technical know-how in SUT construction and understanding of the requirements of the 1993 
SNA and its updates in SNA revision 1. This will be very useful in data analysis and the 
preparation of the key indicators.

15.  Upon the successful completion of the RETA, participating DMCs will have satisfied 
minimum  requirements  for  1993  SNA  compliance  and  acquired  the  know-how  to  analyze 
revisions in GDP levels resulting from 1993 SNA compliance and estimate reliable expenditure 
weights for future PPP calculations. A concluding regional workshop will be conducted to share 
the lessons of the project 
 
16.  Towards the end of the RETA, a publication of the SUTs and the minimum requirement 
datasets for the participating DMCs will be produced. The publication will include data sources 
and collection strategies, data assessment reports and other relevant reports. The publication 
will be circulated among NSOs and other relevant agencies in the region. To disseminate the 
important output of this RETA, it is proposed that the resulting tables be published on the ADB 
website under the economic and statistics webpage, as well as on the websites of participating 
NSOs. A concluding workshop will be held before RETA completion, at which participating 
DMCs will present their results and their future courses of action to ensure the sustainability of 
SUT compilation; address the low compliance rate and data gaps, should any still exist; and 
take on the challenges that will arise from the revisions of the 1993 SNA.  
 
C.   Cost and Financing 
17.  The total cost of the RETA is estimated to be $800,000. It will be financed as a grant by 
ADB’s  technical  assistance  funding  program  and  cover  consulting  services;  training  and 
workshops;  data  collection,  assessment,  and  analysis;  equipment;  and  administrative  and 
support costs. The detailed cost estimates are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  ADB will be the Executing Agency for the RETA, with national statistical offices or 
agencies in charge of the compilation of national accounts as Implementing Agencies. The 
administration  of  the RETA  will  be  handled  by  the  Economics  and  Research  Department. 
Confirmation of no-objection will be obtained from the government of each participating DMC 
prior  to  starting  RETA  activities  in  each  such  DMC,  in  coordination  with  their  regional 
departments3.   
 
19.  The RETA will be implemented from September 2008 to December 2010 and finance 30 
person-months of consulting services: 5 international and 25 national. The consultants will be 
selected and engaged individually by ADB in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). The terms of reference of the consultants 
are in Appendix 3.   
 
20.  ADB will procure computer hardware and software in accordance with its Procurement 
Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time), and this equipment will be disposed of in 
accordance with instructions on administering grant-financed technical assistance.4

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultant: National Accounts Expert (5 person-months, intermittent) 
1.  The  international  consultant  should  be  an  economist  or  statistician  with  extensive 
experience working in the area of national accounts, specifically in the development of a supply 
and use framework and the compilation of the minimum requirement datasets for compliance 
with 1993 System of National Accounts (SNA) recommendations. He or she will have sufficient 
practical  knowledge  handling  household  and  establishment  survey  data,  as  well  as 
administrative-based data. Preferably, he or she will have a working knowledge of the statistical 
systems of developing member countries (DMCs) that participate in this regional technical 
assistance (RETA). 
2.  The particular responsibilities of the consultant will include but not be limited to the 
following: 
 
(i)  Assist the project officer in reviewing the current system of national accounts and 
estimation  procedures  of  participating  DMCs  and  determine  the  scope  of 
production  and  expenditure  data  collection  that  the  DMCs  will  need  for  the 
construction of supply and use tables (SUTs) and the compilation of the minimum 
requirement datasets. 
 
(ii)  Assess the extent to which participating DMCs compile their national accounts on 
the basis of the 1968 SNA, construct a bridge table that will reconcile these 
accounts to the recommendations of the 1993 SNA, and ensure consistency in 
approach among countries in the Asia and Pacific region as well as in 1993 SNA-
compliant countries.  
 
(iii)  Based on country submissions, assess the existing statistical system and the 
database management of each participating DMC to determine the areas that 
need to be prioritized and the activities to be conducted to address data gaps.  
 
(iv)  Prepare templates and data assessment forms to document findings. 
 
(v)  On the basis of (i), (ii), (iii), (iv), and discussions with participating DMCs, (a) 
establish the concepts, definitions, and procedures to construct the supply and 
use  framework  for  data  gap  assessment  and  SUT  compilation  within  each 
country; (b) prepare the most appropriate strategy to fill the data gaps for each 
participating DMC; (c) define sets of proxy indicators and methodologies that can 
be used to complete the seven tables required for 1993 SNA compliance; (d) 
develop  a  framework  that  will  provide  expenditure  weights  of  the  national 
accounts  at  the  155  basic  headings  as  outlined  in  the  2005  International 
Comparison Program; and (e) provide a standard tabulation plan to meet all 
deliverables. 
 
(vi)  Work  with  the  national  statistical  offices  of  participating  DMCs,  national 
consultants,  and  the  project  officer  to  prepare  the  SUTs  and  the  minimum 
requirement datasets. 
 
(vii)  Participate as resource person in workshops and trainings.

12  Appendix 3 
 
(viii)  Provide  technical  guidance  to  national  consultants  in  finalizing  their  working 
papers and SUTs. 
 
(ix)  Provide suggestions on the preliminary set of SUTs and minimum requirement 
datasets submitted by participating DMCs. 
 
(x)  Prepare a report on items (i) to (ix). 
 
(xi)  Assist ERD staff in writing a paper for the project report analyzing the final sets of 
SUTs and the minimum requirement datasets. 
 
 
B.  National Consultant: Economist/Statistician (25 person months) 
1.  The national consultant should have a strong background in economics and statistics, 
with extensive prior working experience in the area of national accounts, specifically on the 
development of the supply and use framework and the compilation of the minimum requirement 
datasets for compliance with 1993 SNA recommendations. He or she should have sufficient 
practical  knowledge  in  handling  household  and  establishment  survey  data,  as  well  as 
administrative-based data. He or she must be adept in using statistical analysis software and in 
database management.  
 
2.  Under the guidance and supervision of the project officer, the national consultant will 
perform the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Provide technical and administrative support to the project officer, ERD staff, and 
international consultant of the RETA. 
 
(ii)  Assist in the preparation and organization of relevant materials and outputs for 
data assessment, research, training, and workshops.  
 
(iii)  Assist in the organization of workshops and training for participating DMCs and in 
preparing the technical documentation for various meetings that will be organized 
as part of the RETA activities. 
 
(iv)  Assist in the preparation of the book on the resulting supply and use framework 
and on 1993 SNA compliance by participating DMCs. 
 
(v)  Assist in the preparation of the final report of the RETA. 
 
(vi)  Perform other tasks as needed.
